description: This dataset contains hourly measurements of particulate matter (PM10) air pollution across monitoring stations in Great Britain during 2017. It's part of the UK's national air quality monitoring network and is used to track air pollution levels, assess compliance with air quality standards, and study environmental health impacts.

original_source.creator: Ricardo Energy and Environment
original_source.institution: UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA)
original_source.publication: Part of the UK-AIR (UK Air Information Resource) database

columns.name: Site ID
columns.semantic_description: Unique identifier for the air quality monitoring station

columns.name: Location
columns.semantic_description: Geographic location or name of the monitoring station

columns.name: Date Time
columns.semantic_description: Timestamp of the measurement in hourly intervals

columns.name: Site Type
columns.semantic_description: Classification of monitoring station (e.g., urban, rural, roadside)

columns.name: Latitude
columns.semantic_description: Geographic latitude coordinate of the monitoring station

columns.name: Longitude
columns.semantic_description: Geographic longitude coordinate of the monitoring station

columns.name: Region
columns.semantic_description: Administrative region or area where the station is located

target_description.name: PM10_particulate_matter_Hourly_measured
target_description.meaning: Concentration of particulate matter with diameter less than 10 micrometers (PM10) in the air

dataset_history: This dataset is part of the UK's long-term air quality monitoring program, which began in the 1970s. The data collection follows EU directive requirements for air quality monitoring and reporting. The monitoring network was significantly expanded in the 2000s to provide better coverage of urban areas and major pollution sources. The year 2017 data is particularly significant as it represents a period of increased focus on urban air quality issues in the UK.
inference_notes:
Important considerations include:
1. Missing values may occur due to equipment maintenance or malfunction
2. Measurements can be affected by local conditions and weather patterns
3. Urban stations typically show higher readings than rural ones
4. Seasonal variations are common with higher readings in winter
5. Data quality follows strict QA/QC procedures set by DEFRA
6. Some monitoring stations may be positioned near known pollution sources, creating potential sampling bias
7. The hourly temporal resolution allows for analysis of daily and seasonal patterns
